questions.answer_description:
protect - The PFC drops packets with unknown source addresses until you remove a sufficient number of secure MAC addresses to drop below the maximum value. restrict - The PFC drops packets with unknown source addresses until you remove a sufficient number of secure MAC addresses to drop below the maximum value and causes the security violation counter to increment. shutdown - Puts the interface into the error-disabled state immediately and sends an SNMP trap notification.
Restrict increments the counter and sends an SNMP trap. And shutdown puts the interface in err-disabled state.

comments.content:
A and D
And shutdown puts the interface in err-disabled state.

discussion.content:
I don't agree with this. According to Cisco's documentation, there are 3 ways a port can react if there is a port-security violation:

protect: Drops all the packets from the insecure hosts at the port-security process level but does not increment the security-violation count.
restrict: Drops all the packets from the insecure hosts at the port-security process level and increments the security-violation count.
shutdown: Shuts down the port if there is a security violation.

https://www.cisco.com/c/m/en_us/techdoc/dc/reference/cli/nxos/commands/l2/switchport-port-security-violation.html

While I agree that the answers given are correct by the documentation, a very good argument can
be made for answer E as well. If you have worked with this stuff long enough you will have seen
this log message that does appear on the console.

*Mar 1 02:00:02.643: %PORT_SECURITY-2-PSECURE_VIOLATION: Security violation occurred, caused by MAC address ecf4.bb65.371f on port FastEthernet0/5.

As you can see it is level 2 which is a critcal message. So it may be better to change the wording
on E to maybe level 1 or level 4. Just my opinion.

questions.question_text: In which two ways can a port respond to a port-security violation? (Choose two.)

choices.C: The port triggers an EEM script to notify support staff and continues to forward traffic normally
choices.A: The port enters the err-disabled state
choices.D: The SecurityViolation counter is incremented and the port sends an SNMP trap
choices.E: The SecurityViolation counter is incremented and the port sends a critical syslog message to the console
choices.F: The port immediately begins to drop all traffic
choices.B: The port enters the shutdown state

choices.A: It is an access port configured for a phone and a PC
choices.B: It is a trunk port and the native VLAN is VLAN1
choices.C: It is a trunk port and the native VLAN m VLAN 700
choices.D: It is an access port in VLAN 700 B

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit, which statement abort the current configuration on port GigabitEthernet2/0/1 is true?
//IMG//

discussion.content: Trunking overides the access vlan command so the answer is B

B is the correct answer
 When port configure as an access port and trunk port at the same time, it will operate as a trunk port by default.
Native Vlan is 1, B rigth answer..

choices.D: Port security is still enabled on the older network switch port.
choices.B: Port security sticky is disabled on the new network switch port.
choices.A: Port security sticky exists on the new network switch port.
choices.E: Port security sticky is still enabled on the older network switch port.
choices.C: Port security must be disabled on all access ports.

discussion.content:
I think, D E

Port security enabled on old switch port with sticky MAC of PC on that port prevent normal connection on new port.

questions.question_text:
An enterprise network has port security sticky enabled on all access ports.
A network administrator moves a PC from one office desk to another.
After the PC is moved, the network administrator clears the port security on the new network switch port connecting to the PC, but the port keeps going back into err-disabled mode. Which two factors are possible causes of this issue? (Choose two)
Which of the following HSRP router states does an active router enter when it is preempted by a higher priority router?

discussion.content: Seems to be correct as now the router will participate in standby election.

choices.F: They have been configured with the spanning-tree guard root command.
choices.B: They have been configured with the spanning-tree bpdufilter enable command.
choices.E: They have been configured with the spanning-tree guard loop command.
choices.D: They have been configured with the spanning-tree bpduguard enable command.
choices.C: They have been configured with the spanning-tree bpduguard disable command.
choices.A: They have been configured with the spanning-tree bpdufilter disable command.
